slides.title: Learning Objectives

Lesson
objectives

• Configure the behavior of the FNOL Wizard

slides.title: i Wizards
slides.originalNotes:
Wizards
This lesson discusses the FNOL (First Notice of Loss) Wizard, but there are several other wizards in the base application, most of which concern the creation of payments. The principles of organization for the FNOL Wizard apply to these other wizards as well.
The steps available in a wizard can vary based on conditions like loss type and policy type. The steps shown above are for a Personal Auto claim.
slides.notes:

slides.title: i Comparing wizards to location
slides.originalNotes:
Comparing wizards to location groups
Wizards — like location groups — are locations. Both have a side bar listing multiple pages or steps. They also have an info bar and actions menu which are shared by these screens.

The principal difference between a wizard and a location group is that a wizard is a list of sequential (and optionally non-sequential) screens, or steps, that together perform some complex task in a logical order
slides.notes:

slides.title: i Contrasting wizards to location
slides.originalNotes:
Contrasting wizards to location groups
A distinction needs to be made between step availability and menu link visibility. Visibility controls whether a menu link appears or not. This functionality is available to both wizard and non-wizard menu links.

Availability controls whether a visible menu link is available or not. This functionality is also available to both wizard and non- wizard menu links.

However, availability for a wizard menu link is typically based on where a user is within the wizard so that, for example, you cannot move directly from step two to step four without completing step three.

Location within a wizard does not typically change a menu link’s visibilityt

slides.title: I Wizard and Wizard Step Structure
slides.originalNotes:
Wizard and Wizard Step Structure
The architecture of a wizard is somewhat simpler than that of a location group. A wizard’s architecture consists of wizard steps, and each wizard step points directly to a screen.
slides.notes:
Wizard and Wizard Step Structure
The architecture of a wizard is somewhat simpler than that of a location group. A wizard’s architecture consists of wizard steps, and each wizard step points directly to a screen.

slides.title: Wizard Entry Points
slides.originalNotes:
Wizard Entry Points
In the example above, the FNOLWizard wizard has four entry points. The third entry point has a signature of "FNOLWizard(Claim)". It expects a single object of type Claim, which is referred to within the PCF page as "Claim".

Locations can have multiple entry points. This is useful when a single location can be referenced from different places with different known pieces of information.

For example, the FNOLWizard can be accessed with no object (as seen in the first entry point), with a set of information including a Policy Type object (as seen in the second entry point), with a claim (as seen in the third entry point), or with a search criteria (as seen in the fourth entry point).
slides.notes:
Wizard Entry Points
In the example above, the FNOLWizard wizard has four entry points. The third entry point has a signature of "FNOLWizard(Claim)". It expects a single object of type Claim, which is referred to within the PCF page as "Claim".

Locations can have multiple entry points. This is useful when a single location can be referenced from different places with different known pieces of information.

For example, the FNOLWizard can be accessed with no object (as seen in the first entry point), with a set of information including a Policy Type object (as seen in the second entry point), with a claim (as seen in the third entry point), or with a search criteria (as seen in the fourth entry point).

slides.title: i Navigating to a wizard
slides.originalNotes:
Navigating to a wizard
Most navigation widgets have an action attribute, which defines where to navigate to when the widget is clicked. The syntax for an action attribute which navigates to a location is:
pcf. LocationEntryPoint. method(objectList), where

LocationEntryPoint is (one of) the location entry point(s) defined on the destination location's Entry Points tab.

method is the method used to navigate to the location (which, for location groups, is almost always "go")-

objectList is a comma- delimited list of zero to many objects. This list must match the number of objects and the type which are expected by the location entry point.
In the example above, the Claim tab has a New Claim menu item- This menu item has an action of "FNOLWizard.go()". The go() method indicates that clicking the menu item should navigate the user to that location. (The empty parentheses indicate that no object is to be passed to that location.) The location to navigate to is the one that has an entry point of "FNOLWizard".

On the Entry Points tab of the FNOLWizard, four entry points have been defined, including one which has no arguments. Because this corresponds to the menu item, this is the location to which the user will be navigated when the user clicks the menu item.
slides.notes:

slides.title: i Mode property
slides.originalNotes:
Mode property
A PCF file can differ based on circumstances like the Loss Type of a claim. The different versions of the PCF are called modes.

The different modes of the PCF file all have the same name, but with different suffixes. The SUfflX is a code drawn from a list. The list may be a defined object, as
shown in the first example, or it can be an explicitly defined pair, as in the second example.

Only legitimate code values from the list are normally allowed. If the value of the mode property evaluates to something that does not match one of the modal suffixes for the PCF, a runtime error occurs — unless there is a -default mode in the modal set, in which case any value of the mode property that does not match any of the other modes defaults to that mode. For this reason, it is usually good practice to create a default mode for any modal PCF you create.
slides.notes:
Mode property
A PCF file can differ based on circumstances like the Loss Type of a claim. The different versions of the PCF are called modes.

The different modes of the PCF file all have the same name, but with different suffixes. The SUfflX is a code drawn from a list. The list may be a defined object, as
shown in the first example, or it can be an explicitly defined pair, as in the second example.

Only legitimate code values from the list are normally allowed. If the value of the mode property evaluates to something that does not match one of the modal suffixes for the PCF, a runtime error occurs — unless there is a -default mode in the modal set, in which case any value of the mode property that does not match any of the other modes defaults to that mode. For this reason, it is usually good practice to create a default mode for any modal PCF you create.

slides.title: i Shared Section Mode
slides.originalNotes:
Shared Section Mode
The Shared Section Mode widget is clickable within Guidewire Studio. Selecting a mode from the widget displays the different modes of the panel set.

Note that the mode property for the Panel or Input Set Ref isgenerated automatically by Studio, and cannot be edited.
slides.notes:
Shared Section Mode
The Shared Section Mode widget is clickable within Guidewire Studio. Selecting a mode from the widget displays the different modes of the panel set.

Note that the mode property for the Panel or Input Set Ref isgenerated automatically by Studio, and cannot be edited.
slides.ocrText:
i Shared Section Mode Gi

When a panel set or an input set has modes, any ref that displays it will always have
a Shared Section Mode widget at the top.
* This widget cannot be added manually

* This widget cannot be moved

slides.title: I Order of wizard steps
slides.originalNotes:
Order of wizard steps
Like the locations in a location group, the steps of a wizard are simply listed sequentially. This list defines the order in which the steps are presented by the wizard in the side bar..

The "Find Policy" step is at the top of the FNOLWizard.pcf file, and applies to claims of all LOBs. Steps 2 and onwards aredetermined by the LOB. The numbering shown above is the steps used by a General Liability claim.
slides.notes:

The "Find Policy" step is at the top of the FNOLWizard.pcf file, and applies to claims of all LOBs. Steps 2 and onwards aredetermined by the LOB. The numbering shown above is the steps used by a General Liability claim.

slides.title: I Steps in the wizard
slides.originalNotes:
Steps in the wizard
The wizard step above is instructive. From the id* property, we know that it represents the Services step of the FNOL wizard.

The screen* propeny tells us the screen which is displayed by this wizard step.

The mode property tells us that there are multiple modes of the screen, and that the mode is selected based on the loss type of the claim.

Because the allowFinish property is set to true, we know that the user can click the Finish button from this step.

Because the available property is set to something other than true, we know that this screen is not available for all claims.
slides.notes:

slides.title: Step sets in the Wizard
slides.originalNotes:
Step sets in the Wizard
The Wizard Step Set serves the purpose of grouping several steps and giving them common availability and visibility properties. Within the step set, the individual steps often have their available and visible properties set to true, so that whenever the step set is available and visible, so are the individual steps.

To add a step to a step set, drag it from the toolbox and drop it in the appropriate spot.
slides.notes:

The Wizard Step Set serves the purpose of grouping several steps and giving them common availability and visibility properties. Within the step set, the individual steps often have their available and visible properties set to true, so that whenever the step set is available and visible, so are the individual steps.

To add a step to a step set, drag it from the toolbox and drop it in the appropriate spot.

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
What is the structure of a wizard?
•
•

questionData.question: What is the structure of a wizard?
questionData.answer: • The correct answer is it is a list of sequential (and optionally non-sequential) steps, that together perform some complex task in a logical order, as a logical unit of work.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
What is the structure of a wizard?
•
•
• The correct answer is it is a list of sequential (and optionally non-sequential) steps,
that together perform some complex task in a logical order, as a logical unit of work.

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
_- — How does a wizard reference a screen, and howis this different from
Ks how a location group references a screen?
•
ee
Gi

questionData.question: How does a wizard reference a screen, and howis this different from
questionData.answer: Ka how a location group references a screen? The correct answer is a wizard directly references a screen via a wizard step, as opposed to a location group which references a screen via a page.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer G
How does a wizard reference a screen, and howis this different from
Ka how a location group references a screen?
•
The correct answer is a wizard directly references a screen via a wizard step, as
opposed to a location group which references a screen via a page.

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
What happens when a screen’s mode property does not match any of
Ks the defined modes?
ee
Gi

questionData.question: What happens when a screen’s mode property does not match any of
questionData.answer: Ka the defined modes? The correct answer is if there is a default mode defined, that mode of the screen is displayed; otherwise, a runtime error occurs.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
What happens when a screen’s mode property does not match any of
Ka the defined modes?
The correct answer is if there is a default mode defined, that mode of the screen is
displayed; otherwise, a runtime error occurs.
